text: football is a really simple game aside
from the offside rule maybe that bond
you have with a football team can be
passed down from a dad to his son maybe
just from one mate to another but once
it's with you it stays with you it was
1992 when the top 22 club split from the
Football League and forms the English
Premier League the Premier League today
is the single most watched sports league
in the world now the first TV deal back
then was worth 50 million pounds a
season then in 1997 it was already two
hundred and twelve million a season the
money went open up this season the clubs
will get nearly 1.8 billion pounds just
from TV if you then add a comparatively
modest matchday income of half a billion
pounds the money from commercial deals
and selling shirts and whatever else
you're over 3 billion pounds a year
that's more than the GDP of a small
country with that much money in the pot
you'd think there'd be plenty to go
around right but apparently not you see
there's actually quite a few players now
who learn more in a couple of weeks than
Barack Obama gets in a whole year those
players are young unbelievably talented
but do they really know what to do with
all that money if a man starts to
color-coordinate his Bentley to his
onesie he has too much money if you ask
me but it's not really the players is it
that kind of money attracts businessman
I know
agents are important but surely so are
the fans
don't get me wrong nobody wants to take
football back to the days of mud bats
and cold pies by the best players make
them rich but you've got to share a
little bit of the wealth with your
supporters they are there with you
getting drenched in mid-november they
make the atmosphere in the stadium and
at the end of the day they make for good
TV 20 years ago you could get a seat
ticket for less than 10 quid and since
then the cost of everything like
people's income and all has gone up by
one hundred and eighty seven percent so
an average ticket should now cost no
more than twenty quid right but it
doesn't the average ticket price that
some clubs is forty one pounds I'll give
you an example my friend Jerry went up
to Manchester for the last match of the
season he spent 48 quid for his ticket
and then 75 quid for the train to go up
there add in a sandwich maybe a pint and
you're close to 150 quid a hundred and
fifty quid that's close to half of what
some fans own in a week it all gets
particularly annoying if you do a bit of
maths and realise just how little it
would actually take to give a slice of
the pie back to the supporters that
newest TV deal is so lucrative that the
price of every single ticket could in
theory be halved and the clubs would
still increase their 2012 profits by
hold your horses 430 million pounds but
for some reason people right at the top
seem to have an unflinching desire to
milk the supporters but you've just got
to know when it's enough because the
league without the fans would be nothing
